page.title: .replace() - Minified.js
page.main:
back to Overview

.replace()

Replaces the list items with the the given node(s) in the DOM tree.

Syntax Variants

$(selector).replace(text)
$(selector).replace(factoryFunction)
$(selector).replace(list)
$(selector).replace(node)

Parameters

text
a text for the text nodes that replace the list elements
callbackFunction
a function that will be invoked for each list element to determine its content. The function can return either a string for a text node, an HTML node or a list containing strings and/or HTML node.
node
content to replace only to the first element of the list with. The content can be a string for a text node, an HTML node or a list containing strings and/or HTML node.
(return value)
the current list

Description

Replaces the list items with the the given node(s) in the DOM tree. If a string has been given, it will be set as text node. If you pass a function, it will be invoked for each list element to create node(s) with the arguments function(parent, index). It can return all values allowed by replace(), including another function to be called. If you pass a list or a function returns a list, all its elements will be set using the rules above.

It is also possible to pass a DOM node, but it will replace only the first element of the list, because DOM does not allow adding it more than once.

Example

Using the following HTML: 

<div id="comments">
   <div id="commentOne">My old comment.</div>
</div>
Replaces the div 'commentOne': 
$('#commentOne').replace('Some new comment.');
This results in: 
<div id="comments">
   Some new comment.
</div>
Please note that not only the text has changed, but the whole <div> has been replaced. If you only want to replace the element's text content you should use fill() instead of replace().

Example

Using the following HTML: 

<ul id="myList">
  <li>First list entry</li>
  <li>Second list entry</li>
</ul>
The following example will replace only the first <li> element: 
$('#myList li').sub(0, 1).replace(EE('li', 'My extra point'));
This results in 
<ul id="myList">
  <li>My extra point</li>
  <li>Second list entry</li>
</ul>
